newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-NSW government to investigate mine deaths.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-NSW government to investigate mine deaths.

text.p: A full investigation will be conducted into the accident at Gretley colliery in New South Wales (NSW) near Newcastle which killed four miners on Thursday, NSW Minerals Minister Bob Martin said.
Martin also announced that the NSW government was proceeding with a Mines Safety Review, foreshadowed in state parliament last month.
The death of four miners in an apparent drowning at Gretley colliery near Newcastle brought to ten the number of deaths in NSW mines since March 1995, a spokesman for Martin said.
It appeared that a number of co-workers at Gretley, about 100 metres from the coalface, were washed by the floodwaters which drowned the four miners, he said.
The flood reached a height one foot (30 cm) from the ceiling of the tunnel, he said, adding: "They are lucky to be alive."
The minister's spokesman confirmed that the accident occurred at a depth of 120 metres but said dimensions of the tunnel were presently unknown.
A full mine investigation would be conducted by the minister into the accident, he said.
The Mines Inspectorate branch of the Department of Mineral Resources was conducting an immediate investigation separate but aligned to the Mines Safety Review, he said.

The mine in the Hunter Valley, Australia's second largest coal district, is owned by Oakbridge Ltd. Oakbridge is 42-percent owned by the U.S. Cyprus Amax mining group, the second largest coal producer in the United States, which has been expanding its coal operations in Australia.
